title: How many total complaints of suspected Internet crime will the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) report for 2019?
preds: How many total complaints of suspected Internet crime will the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) report for 2019? With no real data to chew on, I'll hedge a littel more.

An average increase of about 20k per year, but more recent periods suggest that the 2019 rate of increase will be above that. However, I don't see it being above 75k, which is needed to hit the final bracket.

How many total complaints of suspected Internet crime will the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) report for 2019? Cybercrimes are an instrument of state policy, and appeal to non-state actors as well, we'll continue to see an increase.

According to the  2018 IC3 report, there was a significant increase in cryptocurrency-related crimes. It is worth noting that the cryptocurrency had just experienced a significant spike in value (Dec 2017 - Jan 2018). And although there was a subsequent drop in value,  its value remained much higher than in preceding years. This is corroborated by the significant increase in associated victim's losses for 2018. Since then, the average value of the cryptocurrency has remained relatively flat.  Consequently, the cryptocurrency-related crime rate should trend downwards albeit slowly.

Historical data: 2014: 3% increase on 2013
2015: 7%
2016: 4%
2017: 1%
2018: 16% To get in the top bucket we need: 21%
To get in the second bucket we need: 7% Also noting this source although it’s hard to make much of it for this question: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_data_breaches

Cyber crime of various forms have seen exponential rise over recent years. New forms of cyber crime - crypto jacking, advanced phishing techniques, novel social engineering, exploitation of IoT are also emerging rapidly. Cyber crime techniques have mutated rapidly to counter the defenses being put in place. Growing mass adoption of mobile banking and social media  across the population is likely to increase the impact and frequency of cyber crimes. Awareness campaigns, counter measures, crackdown on dark web market places are unlikely to keep pace with the rate of development and deployment of cyber crime. Year to year crime rate growth, increase in public awareness of crime reporting sites such as IC3 are likely to result in an increase in the number of crimes reported at IC3.  The 375000 ~ 425000 confidence interval represents a 6.5% ~ 20% band of increase in reported crime which I think is a reasonable estimate. Considering the trend, a substantial decrease (325000 or less) marginal decrease or increase (within 325000 ~ 375000 band) than 2018 figures is highly unlikely (10% likelihood). Also, according to me greater than 20% reporting of crime (425000 and more band) is also unlikely (15% likelihood) unless massive cyber crime public awareness campaigns are undertaken which has significant impact.
If this is indicative, then probably need to slide higher. https://www.darkreading.com/attacks-breaches/2019-trending-as-worst-year-on-record-for-data-breaches/d/d-id/1336348

It looks like the typical increase is between 5,000 - 15,000. Average is 300,000. Last five years was roughly 265k, 275k, 285k, 300k, 300k, and 352k. Highest likelihood is B. There's some chance of a return to the mean or A, but I'd be surprised to see this number drop much, if at all. Two years of 50K increase seems a stretch, unless they are doing some kind of major outreach. Slim chance.

Growth rate extrapolation puts this close to 375K threshold. That being said, several major US data breaches in 2019 (CapitalOne, Customs and Border Protection which the FBI is probably quite interested in, Facebook settlement) push the estimate towards the top of the growth extrapolation bracket.

Total no. complaints has increased each year since 2013; each year-on-year increase was in the range x1.03 - x1.07. The above probability weightings assume the next year-on-year increase continues this trend, with some possibility of a decrease on the scale seen in 2011 and 2012 (x0.91, x0.92).
Hard one to call but 2019 seems to have been anecdotally as bad if not a lot worse than 2018

How many total complaints of suspected Internet crime will the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) report for 2019? Linear extrapolation from previous year yeilds a large number. More tools more motivation for mischief.

This is an interesting data set. Looking at past reports, the number of reports grew from 16,000 to 330,000 from 2000 to 2009. From 2009 to 2013, the number of reports shrunk from 330,000 to 260,000. Since 2013, the number of reports has grown 260,000 to the present number of 351,937. So there are 3 pretty distinct periods in the data, two periods of growth, and one of decline. We're in a period of growth, but it may not hold.  When I ran simulations on the data, my predictions reflected that. Using the full sample, the data says to put most of the weight in the two extreme categories, and little in the middle. Using the past 5 years of data, most of the weight should go to the middle. So the main question is what is the most representative sample.
